title: Whole-Body Vibration and Resistance Training in Postmenopausal Women With Low Bone Mass: Effects on Musculoskeletal Health

viii 
 
ABSTRACT 
Background: Obesity is an ongoing socio-economic worldwide epidemic and major modifiable 
risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD), which continues to be the main determinant of all-cause 
mortality. A potential mechanism by which obesity associates with CVD is an increased 
stiffness of the arteries leading to a decreased vascular function and development of 
hypertension. Moreover, muscle strength and mass are inversely related to arterial stiffness and 
obesity. Although exercise training is a proficient intervention for treating CVD risk factors and 
increasing muscle strength/mass, the most effective intervention for decreasing arterial stiffness 
is still unclear. Whole-body vibration training (WBVT) is a relatively novel exercise mode 
which requires static or dynamic movements on a vibrating platform and has similar adaptations 
in the skeletal muscle as resistance training (RT). However, the effects of whole-body high 
intensity RT seem to be adverse, although controversial to arterial function in young healthy 
adults and middle-aged with prehypertension or hypertension. WBVT is usually performed with 
leg exercises using the body weight (unloaded) as resistance to the exercise. However, the 
addition of an external load or resistance to WBVT (WBVT+EX) has shown beneficial 
adaptations in improving arterial function, bone mineral density, hormonal responses, and 
muscle strength/mass. Purpose: The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether WBVT+EX 
would induce greater benefits than unloaded WBVT on arterial function and muscle strength in 
young-overweight and obese (body mass index, BMI= 30.9 ± 0.7 kg/m 2) women.
sections.methods:
Twenty-two young (20 ± 1 yr) overweight/obese women were randomly assigned to a non-
exercising overweight/obese control (O-CON), WBVT, or WBVT+EX for 6 weeks. Thirteen 
lean women were assigned to a lean control (L-CON) group in order to compare them at baseline 
to the age-matched overweight/obese women. Pulse wave velocity (PWV), brachial blood 

ix 
 
pressure (BP), aortic BP, wave reflection, muscle strength, and body composition were measured 
before and after 6 weeks. Results: Statistical significance was set at P < 0.05. Data were 
presented as mean ± SE. There were no significant time effects or group-by-time interactions for 
brachial-ankle PWV (baPWV), carotid-femoral P WV (cfPWV), brachial systolic BP (bSBP), 
brachial diastolic BP (bDBP), aortic diastolic BP (aDBP), augmentation index (AIx), 
augmentation pressure ( AP), and transit time for the reflected wave ( Tr). cfPWV and aSBP 
decreased (P < 0.05) in the WBVT group while baPWV and aDBP decreased in the WBVT+EX. 
There was a significant group-by time interaction ( P < 0.01) for faPWV, aSBP, aortic mean 
arterial pressure (aMAP), and AIx adjusted at 75 bpm (AIx@75). In addition, group- by-time 
interaction was detected for P1 and P2 such that the reductions observed in the WBVT and 
WBVT+EX groups were significantly different (P < 0.05) from the O-CON group. The WBVT 
and the WBVT+EX groups had significant increases in leg strength ( P < 0.01) when compared 
to the O-CON group (group-by-time P < 0.01) while a time-effect (P < 0.01) was observed in the 
chest 1RM only in the WBVT+EX group.
sections.conclusion:
To our knowledge, this is the first study 
to detect beneficial effects of WBVT+EX on arterial parameters, as shown by improvements in 
aortic BP, PWV, and wave reflection while still maintaining increases in muscle strength in 
young overweight/obese women. Although unloaded WBVT seems to be an effective exercise 
modality to improve arterial function in obese postmenopausal women, it does not seem to be as 
efficient in young obese women. This study suggests that, although WBVT had some positive 
effects on arterial function in young overweight/obese women, a more evident benefit on arterial 
function is observed after increasing the exercise intensity of WBVT through an external load 
progressed from 15 to 8 RM. Future studies should focus on older populations with greater risk 
of cardiovascular and/or other chronic diseases that are associated with reduced muscle 

x 
 
strength/mass. WBVT+EX should be incorporated and recommended for young 
overweight/obese women in order to improve arterial function and prevent the loss in muscle 
mass related to weight loss. Additional studies should also consider the use of WBVT+EX as an 
adjunct exercise modality in order to incorporate its use in clinical populations prone to physical 
disabilities due to sarcopenia and dynapenia. 

1 
 
CHAPTER ONE 
BACKGROUND AND SIGNIFICANCE 
 
 The incidence of obesity is increasing independently of ethnicity, race and age [1]. 
Obesity is a major modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), which continues to 
be the main cause of mortality and morbidity worldwide [2]. Obese individuals display higher 
blood pressure (BP) levels than non-obese individuals increasing the probability of adverse 
cardiovascular outcomes [3]. A potential mechanism by which obesity is associated with CVD 
is an increased stiffness of central arteries (carotid and aorta), a change that is more pronounced 
in younger than older individuals [4]. Obesity is considered a strong link between impaired 
endothelial function and the development of atherosclerosis in men and women [5-7]. Arterial 
stiffness, assessed by pulse wave velocity (PWV), is an independent predictor of CVD [8-9] and 
is increasingly recognized as a valid endpoint of CVD [10-11]. Recent evidence indicates that 
obesity may increase carotid-femoral PWV (cfPWV) [12-13] and femoral-ankle PWV (faPWV) , 
but not arm PWV in young adults [13]. Furthermore, obesity has previously been linked to 
increases in pressure wave reflection to the aorta (augmentation index, AIx), indicating increased 
smooth muscle vasomotor tone [14-15]. An increased vasomotor tone leads to vasoconstriction 
that can explain the increases in PWV and AIx that lead to hypertension or CVD in young obese 
women [16]. 
Muscle strength and mass are positively correlated to cardiovascular health in adults [17] 
and inversely associated with obesity [18] and PWV [19]. Reduced muscle strength relative to 

2 
 
excessively high body mass impedes the weight-bearing activities that are vital for maintaining a 
healthy lifestyle [20]. 
 Conventional exercise modalities such as resistance [21-22], aerobic [23-25], and 
isometric [26-27] exercise training as well as the combination of aerobic and resistance exercise 
[28-29] have previously shown plausible cardiovascular and muscular function benefits. 
Although resistance training (RT) is the preferred exercise modality to improve muscle strength 
and mass [30-32], it may cause deleterious effects on central and peripheral arteries as shown as 
increases in cfPWV, faPWV, and AIx in young and middle-aged adults [33-35], despite other 
known benefits on muscle function, bone mineral density, and glucose control. 
 Whole-body vibration (WBV) is a novel exercise modality that has previously shown to 
improve muscle strength and mass via a mechanical stimulus generated by a vibrating platform, 
stimulating muscle spindle activity and, consequently, increasing muscle mass and strength [36]. 
Improvements in muscle strength have been observed in young overweight/obese women after 
WBV training (WBVT) 3 times a week for 6 weeks [37] as well as 2 times a week for 10 weeks 
[38]. Moreover, previous research established lower extremity hemodynamic benefits through 
blood flow increases in skin, popliteal artery, and vastus lateralis [39-41] following acute bouts 
of passive vibration, static squat WBV, and dynamic squat WBV, respectively. The combination 
of WBV with an external load determines a more evident stimulus [42] and greater energy 
expenditure [43-44], which can be incremented when an external load is superimposed to 
dynamic squats performed with WBV [45]. A previous study demonstrated that applying an 
external load to WBV was more effective than RT without vibration for preventing deleterious 
changes in the femoral artery caused by complete physical inactivity for 60 days [46]. 
Therefore, the potential benefits of combining WBV and external load to amplify muscular 

3 
 
benefits while maintaining or improving the benefits on arterial function in young 
overweight/obese women remain to be investigated. 
 
Statement of the Problem 
 Obese women exhibit higher levels of arterial dysfuntion as observed by increased 
measurements of arterial stiffness and wave reflection that progressively lead to hypertension. 
Moreover, the decreased muscle strength/mass observed in these women may lead to conditions 
such as sarcopenia and dynapenia, which increase the risk not only for cardiovascular events but 
also a sedentary lifestyle. An exercise modality that can both maintain or improve arterial 
function and increase muscle strength/mass is important in order to decrease the likelihood of 
cardiovascular events We evaluated whether 6 weeks of a combined WBVT and external load 
would induce greater benefits than unloaded WBVT on arterial and muscular function in young 
overweight/obese women. 
 
Specific Aims and Hypotheses 
AIM 1: To determine the effects of 6 weeks of WBVT+EX (Externally loaded, resistive WBVT) 
compared to WBVT (unloaded WBVT) and O-CON (overweight/obese control) on vascular 
function. This aim examined the working hypothesis that WBVT+EX (external load in vest 
corresponding to the subjects’ 8 -15 repetition maximum (RM)) would result in a decrease in 
arterial stiffness, AIx, and BP (brachial and aortic). This aim was tested by non-invasive 
measures of arterial stiffness using PWV of three arterial segments (cfPWV, faPWV, and 
baPWV). Sensory pressure cuffs in the arms and ankles as well as two tonometers placed in the 
carotid and femoral arteries obtained the aforementioned arterial segments. Aortic BP and AIx 

4 
 
were assessed through pulse wave analysis using applanation tonometry of the radial artery. 
Hypothesis 1: 6 weeks of WBVT+EX would result in greater decreases in AIx, BP, and PWV (at 
rest) when compared to WBVT and O-CON. 
AIM 2: To determine the effects of 6 weeks of WBVT+EX compared to WBVT and O-CON on 
muscle strength. This specific aim examined the working hypothesis that WBVT +EX would 
result in greater increase in muscle strength. This aim was tested through one RM strength test 
(1RM) of the chest press and leg press exercises. 
Hypothesis 2: 6 weeks of WBVT+EX intervention would produce greater increases in muscle 
strength when compared to WBVT and O-CON. In addition, the increase in leg muscle strength 
after unloaded WBVT would be significant compared with no changes in the O-CON group. 
AIM 3: To determine the effects of 6 weeks of WBVT+EX compared to WBVT and O-CON on 
body composition. This specific aim examined the working hypothesis that WBVT+EX would 
result in increased leg lean mass (LM) compared to WBVT and O-CON. This aim was tested by 
the dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA). 
Hypothesis 3: 6 weeks of WBVT+EX intervention would produce greater improvements in leg 
LM compared to WBVT and O-CON. 
 
Assumptions 
The subsequent assumptions were taken into consideration in this study: 
1. All laboratory equipment recorded precise and accurate measurements. 
2. All participants were truthful when reporting their previous and current health history. 
3. All participants followed the pre-test recommendations (e.g. physical activity, alcohol 
consumption, and medication). 

5 
 
4. All participants maintained their daily activities, current lifestyle and followed the 
guidelines set forth by the researcher during their participation in the study. 
5. All participants performed the assigned exercises to their maximum effort. 
 
 Delimitations 
This study incorporated the following delimitations: 
1. 25 overweight/obese (BMI between 27 kg/m 2
 
and 40 kg/m 2) and 13 lean (BMI < 25 
kg/m2) pre-menopausal women (ages 18-25 years) were enrolled in this study. 
2. Participants were excluded from the study if they were pregnant, regularly exercised ( > 
120 min of light to moderate (<70% VO 2max or 1RM) exercise per week), smoked, had a 
resting BP ≥160/90 mmHg, fell outside the BMI range ( BMI between 27 kg/m 2
 
and 40 
kg/m2) (for the WBVT+EX, WBVT, and O-CON groups) and/or were on any 
medications that affected the outcome variables. 
3. Participants were excluded if they had chronic diseases including epilepsy, gallstones, 
kidney stones, acute inflammations, arthritis, joint implants, recent thrombosis, recent 
operative wounds, intense migraines, tumors, hernias, uncontrolled diabetes, and 
cardiovascular or kidney diseases. 
 
Limitations 
1. The participants in this study were volunteers and, therefore, represented a range of 
unique characteristics that may have affected the validity of the results. 

6 
 
2. A limitation exists when measuring cardiovascular function at rest. The influence of 
various factors (e.g. environmental and dietary) may have a direct influence in 
cardiovascular function and affect the results. 
3. The participants of this study consisted of pre-menopausal women. Because arterial 
stiffness [47], arterial pressure waveforms [48], and arterial compliance [47] are 
influenced by the menstrual cycle, measurements were conducted during the follicular or 
late luteal phase of their menstrual cycle in order to avoid the vasoactive effects of 
estrogen. Also, because the study consisted of a 6-week period, only women with stable 
ovulatory cycle duration over at least the last 2 months were eligible for the study [49]. 
 
Definition of terms and abbreviations 
1RM- One repetition maximum, defined as the maximum amount of weight that can be moved 
through a full range of motion. 
AIx- Augmentation index, the differences between the first and second systolic peak divided by 
the pulse pressure and multiplied by 100. AIx is considered a marker of wave reflection [50]. 
baPWV- Brachial to ankle PWV, an index of systemic arterial stiffness [51]. 
cfPWV- Carotid to femoral PWV, an index of aortic arterial stiffness [52]. 
CVD- Cardiovascular diseases. 
eNOS- Endothelial nitric oxide synthase. 
ET-1- Endothelin-1, regulator of vascular tone produced in the endothelial cells that cause 
systemic vasoconstriction [53]. 
faPWV- Femoral to ankle PWV, an index of leg arterial stiffness [52]. 

7 
 
NO- Nitric oxide, signaling molecule involved in the regulation of vascular tone (potent 
vasodilatory effect) [54]. 
P1- First systolic peak, defined as the forward pressure wave caused by stroke volume ejection 
[55]. 
P2- Second systolic peak, defined as the peripheral reflection of the pressure wave; also 
considered a marker of vascular tone [50]. 
PWV- Pulse wave velocity, an index of arterial stiffness [51-52]. 
Tr- Time of reflection, indicates the transit time of the reflected wave; defined as the round-trip 
travel of the forward wave to the peripheral reflecting sites and back to the aorta [56]. 
WBVT- Whole-body vibration training, novel training method employing mechanical 
stimulation through vibration to exercise musculoskeletal structures for the improvement of 
muscle mass, muscle strength [38,57-63] and cardiovascular health [37, 64-65]. 
WBVT+EX- Externally loaded WBVT. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

8 
 
CHAPTER TWO 
REVIEW OF LITERATURE
sections.introduction:
Obesity is an ongoing socio-economic worldwide epidemic with approximately 68% of 
United States adults being overweight or obese. In 2011-2012, the prevalence of obesity was 
34.9% amongst adults [66]. The direct and indirect costs of obesity-related conditions account 
for, approximately, $149 billion annually [66]. By 2030, an estimated 51% of the population 
will be obese; an increase of 33% for obesity [67]. Obese and overweight individuals are 
characterized by excess body weight with body mass index (BMI) commonly used as the 
criterion to define these categories [68-69]. Increased BMI is linked to numerous chronic 
diseases and, subsequently, is a strong predictor of higher cardiovascular morbidity and mortality 
in both genders [68, 70-71], as well as numerous musculoskeletal complications. Interestingly, 
Nordstrand et al. [72] found that PWV increased with higher BMI in middle-aged and older 
women, but this increase is not observed in men [4]. Therefore, improving an impaired 
vasculature and its association to an increased arterial stiffness should be pivotal in young obese 
women. Because the reduction of obesity in a care and cost efficient manner is of great 
importance and relevance and exercise training is an essential component in the prevention, 
treatment, and management of obesity [73] and related chronic diseases, an exercise modality 
and prescription that improves cardiovascular function as well as muscular function holds 
pronounced clinical importance. 
 

9 
 
Obesity and Arterial Function 
 Vascular homeostasis is maintained by changes in the vasomotor tone, which regulate BP 
and determine the amount of blood flow distributed to various organs and regions of the body, 
including the skeletal muscle. The vascular tone is determined by the balance between 
vasoconstrictor and vasodilator influences acting on smooth muscle (medial layer) within the 
arterial wall of the blood vessel [74]. These influences can either cause the vessels to constrict 
(increasing resistance and decreasing diameter) or dilate by smooth muscle relaxation 
(decreasing resistance and increasing diameter). The vascular endothelium (innermost layer 
composed of specialized cells) is responsible for originating these intrinsic influences [75]. 
Nitric Oxide (NO) is a gaseous compound produced in the endothelial cells and is 
considered the major regulator of the vascular tone by promoting vasodilation, increasing blood 
flow [76-77] and reducing BP [53]. Endothelial NO synthase (eNOS), which is inversely related 
to BMI [78], is the enzyme responsible of regulating NO production and is activated by physical 
stress (shear stress) exerted upon the arterial wall [79]. 
 
 
Figure 1. Nitric oxide production. eNOS, endothelial nitric oxide synthase; L-arg, L-arginine; 
NO, nitric oxide. 

10 
 
Physical exercise is a powerful stimulus to increase shear stress and endothelial NO 
production, resulting in local vasodilation in the exercised muscles [80-81]. On the contrary, 
endothelin-1 (ET-1) is another regulator of vascular tone produced in the endothelial cells that 
causes systemic vasoconstriction, decreasing blood flow, and increasing BP [53]. One of the 
possible mechanisms associated to endothelial dysfunction results from a reduced bioavailability 
of NO and predominance of vasoconstrictor influences (such as ET-1) acting on the vascular 
smooth muscle [82]. 
Obesity and Arterial Dysfunction 
Arterial stiffness, an independent predictor for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality 
assessed by PWV, results from the loss of arterial vasodilatory capacity in the major arteries. 
Nordstrand et al. [72] found that increased BMI, waist circumference, and fat mass were 
independently associated with higher cfPWV or aortic stiffness in women, but not in men. 
Furthermore, Zebekakis et al. [4] reported that the association between arterial stiffness of the 
carotid artery and BMI was more pronounced at younger than older age. Therefore, the 
increased arterial stiffness observed in overweight/obese individuals can be attributed to a 
functional change of the arterial wall rather than the age-related structural change in the arterial 
wall. This structural change observed with aging occurs in the connective tissue of the arterial 
wall with decreased elastin and increased collagen fiber resulting in an increased velocity of the 
pulse pressure wave [83]. 
PWV is calculated as the distance travelled by a pulse wave between two arteries in 
different segments of the body in relation to the time it takes or transit time of the wave [52]. 
Pulse waves are composed of an incidence or forward wave that originates from the stroke 
volume during ventricular systole. This initial wave travels from the aorta to peripheral arteries 

11 
 
and meets bifurcations, small peripheral arteries, and arterioles [84] causing a second wave that 
is reflected back to the aorta during ventricular diastole in healthy individuals at rest. In healt hy 
young individuals, the pressure of the reflected wave (P2) is smaller than the forward wave (P1) 
resulting in a reduced augmented pressure (P2-P1) [85]. 
 
 
Figure 2. Pulse wave velocity in main segments: baPWV, brachial-ankle pulse wave velocity 
(systemic); cfPWV, carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (aorta); faPWV, femoral-ankle pulse 
wave velocity (leg). 

12 
 
As arterial stiffness increases, reflected wave amplitude increases and augments pressure 
in late systole, producing an increase in left ventricular afterload, and myocardial oxygen 
demand [86]. The augmented pressure expressed as a percentage of the pulse pressure is known 
as the AIx, which is an index of wave reflection and left ventricular afterload [55]. It is well 
known that heart rate negatively influences the AIx. Therefore, AIx is normalized to 75 
beats/min [87]. Obese individuals have previously been linked to elevated levels of AIx [15]. 
Furthermore, in a recent study, Pierce et al. [12] studied overweight/obese adolescents and found 
that an increased total and abdominal adiposity is associated with greater aortic stiffness and 
lower pulse pressure amplification. Transit time for the reflected wave ( Tr) represents the time 
from the onset of the ejected pulse waveform to the onset of the reflected wave and is an estimate 
of aortic PWV [88]. These central aortic pressures more accurately reflect loading c onditions of 
the left ventricular myocardium, coronary arteries, and cerebral vasculature and, thereby, relate 
better to adverse cardiovascular events than brachial pressures [89]. 
 
 
Figure 3. Aortic pressure waveform. Depicts the features of the aortic pulse pressure waveform. 
AIx, augmentation index; AP, augmentation pressure; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; P1, first 
systolic peak; PP, pulse pressure; SBP, systolic blood pressure; Tr, transit time of reflected wave. 

13 
 
Resistance Exercise 
 Resistance exercise is widely accepted in exercise prescription, cardiopulmonary 
rehabilitation, and considered an integral component by major health organizations [17,90-91]. 
Furthermore, it has been widely recognized as an efficient intervention for improving muscle 
mass and strength in overweight/obese women [22]. 
 The effects of resistance exercise on cardiovascular health has been a recent topic of great 
debate amongst exercise physiologist primarily because of the discrepancies related to arterial 
function, perhaps, to the wide variability in training protocols, sample size, intensities, and 
targeted muscle groups [92]. Although the association between resistance exercise and increased 
central arterial stiffness is still unclear [92], various studies have had adverse effects on the 
vasculature. The elevation of blood flow for short periods of time under high pressures cause an 
alternative type of stress stimulus on the endothelial cells (combination of shear stress and 
perpendicular force) that may alter the structural composition of the arterial wall [93]. However, 
even though Miyachi et al. [33] reported that 4 months of RT in young and middle-aged men 
significantly reduced central arterial compliance, structural remodeling was ruled out because no 
effect was found on carotid artery intima-media thickness and the negative effects were revers ed 
after 2 months of detraining [34,94]. Deleterious results associated with RT on arterial function 
have been reported in young women through increases in central AIx and PWV [35] as well as in 
young men [95-96]. 
On the other hand, Casey et al. [97] found no change in central and peripheral arterial 
stiffness or in aortic pressure wave characteristics after 12 weeks of sets of 8-12 repe titions to 
volitional fatigue in young non-obese adults. Similarly, Rakobowchuk et al. [98] established that 
12 weeks of whole-body RT gradually progressed to 80% of 1RM in young men did not cause 

14 
 
structural remodeling and decreased both brachial and carotid pulse pressures. Moreover, Olson 
et al. [22] did not observe any significant alteration in carotid artery intima-media thickness on 
healthy young and middle-aged women after RT. Furthermore, Beck et al. [99] obser ved 
decreases in faPWV (or leg PWV) and AIx following 8 weeks of aerobic and RT. However, 
cfPWV (or aortic PWV) was not altered in the previous study. Similarly, Croymans et al. [100] 
did not see changes in cfPWV after 12 weeks of RT 3 times a week in overweight/obese 
sedentary young men. Therefore, the favorable effects of resistance exercise on arterial function 
could be more evident in young pre-hypertensive individuals, a characteristic that is common 
among young obese individuals. Interestingly, a recent study by Figueroa et al. [29] indicated 
improvements in baPWV in postmenopausal women that performed 20 min of moderate 
intensity aerobic exercise after moderate intensity circuit RT in the same training session for 12 
weeks. Therefore, these favorable outcomes could be possibly due to the light- to-moderate-
intensity (60% of 1RM) resistance exercise or that aerobic exercise counteracts the possible 
negative effect of RT. Also, adverse effects of high-intensity resistance exercise seem to be 
mediated by upper-body but not lower-body exercises [101]. 
Whole-Body Vibration and Arterial Stiffness 
 The use of WBV as a new exercise modality has gained wide popularity in research and 
clinical practice. Its use in high-risk populations [102-103], has been widely administered and 
continues to represent a possible adjunct or alternative mode of exercise. WBV produces a 
forced mechanical oscillation or periodic alteration of force, acceleration, and displacement ove r 
time, where energy is transferred from the vibration device to the exposed body part [104]. 
During WBV, subjects stand on a motor-driven vibrating platform maintaining a static position 
or performing dynamic exercises. The sinusoidal vibration stimulus from the platform activates 

15 
 
muscle spindle discharge through the stimulation of alpha-motoneurons [105] causing a muscle 
contraction through the “Tonic Vibration Reflex” [106]. This reaction activates additional motor 
units leading to higher muscular strength [107]. 
 Interestingly, Hazell et al. [108] suggested that the cumulative cardiovascular response to 
WBV with multiple exercises as well as its use in populations with compromised cardiovascular 
function (e.g. overweight-obese individuals) who are unable to perform traditional exercise 
programs should be evaluated to a greater extent. Moreover, the favorable effects of WBV on 
cardiovascular function have been previously considered mainly following acute bouts of WBV. 
However, repeated bouts of acute exercise are important contributors to chronic adaptations, 
which may prevent or delay the development of certain diseases or conditions [109]. Previous 
research found blood flow increases in skin [39], popliteal artery [40], and vastus lateralis [41] 
following acute bouts of passive vibration, static squat WBV, and dynamic squat WBV, 
respectively, reflecting transient lower extremity hemodynamic benefits. Furthermore, Maloney 
et al. [110] reported an increase in NO production and skin blood flow after passive vibration. 
Also, Wong et al. [111], Figueroa et al. [112] and Otsuki et al. [113] all found acute decrease s in 
baPWV following a session of passive or active WBV. These results sustain the potential 
rationale that the exposure or propagation of the vibration stimulus causes a mechanical stimulus 
to leg arteries (arterial compression), therefore, eliciting vasodilatory effects and acutely 
decreasing peripheral and systemic arterial stiffness. Meaningfully, Figueroa et al. [37] , found 
that 6 weeks of WBVT in overweight/obese women decreased brachial and aortic SBP, baP WV, 
and AIx. Interestingly, the WBVT consisted of unloaded and loaded exercises during the first 4 
and last 2 weeks, respectively. Although, there was a decrease in baPWV in the previous study, 
we were unable to evaluate which of the main arterial segments in baPWV (cfPWV and/or 

16 
 
faPWV) were determinants of the improvement in systemic PWV. Therefore, the fact that 
WBVT can be considered a feasible alternative for the reduction of faPWV [65] and a potential 
countermeasure for the arterial dysfunction in young overweight/obese individuals is yet to be 
entirely evaluated. In addition, the possible benefits on arterial stiffness of 6 weeks of 
WBVT+EX (while applying the external load from the beginning) are yet to be fully elucidated. 
Whole-Body Vibration and Strength 
 Previous studies have assessed the viable effects of WBV in muscle strength in various 
populations. WBV has previously produced adaptive neuromuscular responses notable in 
populations with neurological diseases [102-103, 114]. Research has shown that WBV increases 
muscle strength [107, 115-116] in a similar manner than those derived from more traditional 
strength training [57-58, 117-118]. Machado et al. [61] determined that 10 weeks of WBVT has 
a significant effect on strength, muscle mass, muscle power, and mobility in older women. 
Lower limb WBVT produced a significant increase in muscle strength and thigh muscle 
hypertrophy, which would be beneficial to counteract the loss of muscle strength and, 
consequently, function associated with aging and menopause. These results are supported by 
two recent studies [37-38], which evaluated the effects of 6-10 weeks of WBVT on 
anthropometry, body composition, and muscular strength in young obese women and indicated 
that lower limb strength and lean mass increased in the WBV group. However, our previous 
study, although a 6 week intervention, was composed of a 4-week unloaded WBVT and a 2-
week loaded WBVT period (weight vest consisted of 5 and 10% of the participants’ body 
weight). Thus, it is unclear whether unloaded WBVT (low intensity) for 6 weeks would cause 
the same improvements in arterial function and, precisely, muscle strength/mass that 6 weeks of 

17 
 
WBVT+EX would. Therefore, the increase in muscle strength caused by vibration-induced 
muscle activity is of great clinical importance in young overweight/obese women. 
Combination of Whole-Body Vibration and Resistance Exercise 
 As previously addressed, WBVT and RT regimes produce similar adaptive responses and 
have been efficient exercise modalities for improving impaired muscular function [57-58, 117-
119] and arterial function [37,65]. Interestingly, previous studies have evaluated the potential 
amplified benefits of combining these two training modalities on hormonal responses [120,121], 
bone loss prevention [122,123], muscle strength [124], and body composition [125]. Some 
studies have evaluated the chronic [125-127] and acute [128] cardiovascular responses to WBVT 
with external loads but they have focused on muscle capillarization [125], arterial diameter, 
intima-media thickness, flow-mediated dilation [126], HR and brachial BP [127]. However, no 
study has assessed the effects of WBVT+EX in central BP, AIx, and PWV. 
 Two studies by Giunta et al. [120,121] observed the hormonal responses of different 
combinations of WBVT+EX protocols. One study [120] evaluated the acute effects of WBV 
alone combined with squatting plus external load on growth hormone and blood lactate 
concentrations in obese women and saw no additive effect. A later study [121] observed 
significantly greater increases of growth hormone secretion, cortisol, and lactate following the 
combined intervention when compared to the other conditions in healthy young obese women. 
Meanwhile, Belavy et al. [122,123] showed that WBVT+EX during 56 days of bed rest 
(spaceflight simulation) in young-men was able to reduce leg muscle atrophy. WBVT+EX has 
also shown to be more effective than RT without vibration in preventing the adverse effects of 
prolonged inactivity on the femoral artery structure [46]. Likewise, Bemben et al. [124] and 
Fjeldstad et al. [129] assessed the effects of 8 months of RT or WBVT+EX on muscle strength 

18 
 
and body composition, respectively, in post-menopausal women. RT and WBVT+EX 
significantly increased strength for all exercises while WBVT+EX had significantly greater 
percent increases in muscular strength than RT at 4 months. Moreover, Fjeldstad et al. [129] also 
observed positive body composition changes with increased lean tissue in both training groups, 
but only effective decreases in percent body fat were noted in the WBVT+EX group. Therefore, 
the addition of extraload (an additional resistance) to WBV exercise could potentially augment 
the intensity and positive effects of WBV alone on muscular strength and lean tissue. However, 
the effects of WBVT+EX on PWV and wave reflection are not known and are of crucial 
importance for the prevention of cardiovascular and metabolic complications in young 
overweight/obese individuals. 
 Although previous studies have examined the prospective outcomes of superimposed 
external load to WBVT in muscular function [125], this is the first study in young pre-
menopausal overweight/obese women to assess PWV, AIx and central BPs while prescribing the 
superimposed external load to the WBV in order to perform 8-15 repetitions. Developing an 
optimal exercise modality and protocol that improves and facilitates cardiovascular and body 
composition adaptations is imperative while still avoiding the safety concerns and possible 
deleterious effects on arterial stiffness linked to RT programs. Since WBVT+EX was superior to 
RT alone to prevent adverse changes in the femoral artery associated with physical inactivity in 
previous studies, we hypothesized that WBVT+EX would induce greater improvements in leg 
muscle strength and arterial function compared to WBVT alone and O-CON. Therefore, the 
purpose of this study was to examine the potential benefits of WBVT+EX on cardiovascular and 
muscular function following a 6-week intervention in young overweight/obese women. 
 

19 
 
CHAPTER THREE 
RESEARCH METHODOLOGY 
 
Subjects 
 A total of 38 young (age range: 18-25 years) overweight or obese (BMI range: 27 kg/m 2
 
and 40 kg/m 2, n= 25) and lean (BMI < 25 kg/m 2, n=13) women enrolled in this study. Women 
were recruited from the Tallahassee community through announcements and direct 
communication. Subjects were asked to maintain their diet, lifestyle, and exercise habits during 
the study period. The exclusion criteria were based on contraindications to exercise as well as 
WBV contraindications (e.g. nonconsolidated fractures, bone tumors, herniated disks or metal 
implants). Subjects were nonsmokers who did not exercise regularly (> 120 min per week of 
light-moderate intensity exercise). Exclusion criteria included individuals that fell outside of the 
specified BMI range, had a resting BP ≥160/90 mmHg and/or had chronic diseases including 
epilepsy, gallstones, kidney stones, acute inflammations, arthritis, joint implants, recent 
thrombosis, recent operative wounds, intense migraines, tumors, hernias, uncontrolled diabetes, 
and cardiovascular and kidney diseases. Also, if the subject was pregnant or taking any 
medications that affected the outcome variables, the subject was excluded from the study. 
Moreover, due to the 6-week duration of the study, only women with stable ovulatory cycle 
duration over at least the last 2 months were eligible for the study [49].

Experimental Protocol 
 Following an initial screening, overweight/obese participants were randomly assigned 
into 1 of 3 groups for 6 weeks: WBVT+EX, WBVT, or O-CON. The participants reported to the 
Cardiovascular Physiology Laboratory (cardiovascular) and Exercise Physiology Laboratory 
(body composition and muscle strength) at Florida State University for baseline measurements 
and after 6 weeks of the assigned intervention; the supervised training sessions were also held at 
the aforementioned locations. 
Visit #1: Familiarization and Anthropometrics 
 The first visit consisted of a familiarization period where an overview of the study was 
explained. The subject’s anthropometric measurements (height, weight, waist circumference, 
and BMI calculation) and resting brachial BP (after 5 min of rest in the seated position) were 
obtained. If the criterion was met, the participant was asked to complete a medical history 
questionnaire and informed consent form. The participants were also familiarized with the 
exercises that were going to be performed in both WBVT groups as well as the muscle strength 
test exercises (chest and leg press). 
Visit #2: Body Composition and Muscle Strength 
 The participants underwent a non-invasive DEXA scan to determine whole-body and 
regional body composition. The subjects were then warmed-up and progressed to perform a 
1RM muscle strength test (leg press and chest press). 
Visit #3: Cardiovascular Function Measurements and Muscle Strength Confirmation 
 During the third visit (at least 72 hrs following visit 2), measurements were conducted in 
the morning after an overnight (8-12 hrs) fast and during the follicular (days 1-14) or late luteal 
phase (≥day 21) of their ovarian cycle to preve nt the vasoactive effects of estrogens [153]. The 

22 
 
measurements were scheduled based on the subject’s self -reported first day of the menstrual 
cycle. Participants refrained from caffeine, alcohol consumption, prescribed medication or any 
unaccustomed physical activity 24 hrs before test day. All data collection were recorded a t the 
same time of the day (±1 hr in order to avoid diurnal variations) and at least 24-48 hrs after the 
last training session (avoid the acute effects of exercise). All measurements were performed in 
the morning (between 7 and 11am) in a quiet temperature-controlled room (22-24 ⁰C). 
Participants rested in the supine position for at least 10 min before data collection. Following the 
resting period, baseline measurements of electrocardiogram (ECG), brachial BP, PWV (baPWV, 
cfPWV, and faPWV), and pulse wave analysis (wave reflection and aortic BP) were obtained. 
 
 
Figure 6. Hormonal levels during the menstrual cycle. 
 

23 
 
Succeeding the cardiovascular measurements and following the same warm-up as in the 
second visit, the participants confirmed the maximum weight achieved at the prior visit until a 
1RM weight was achieved. The participants were randomized into 1 of 3 groups. Participants 
began their assigned 6-week intervention of WBVT+EX or WBVT. The O-CON did not 
participate in any scheduled exercise for the 6 weeks. All participants were told to maintain 
regular diet and exercise habits. 
Visit #4: Post 6 weeks Body Composition and Muscle Strength 
 Visit 4 consisted of the end of study testing (after 6 weeks of training or non-exercising 
control period). DEXA scan, anthropometry, and muscle strength were measured as in visits 1 
and 2. 
Visit #5: Post 6 weeks Cardiovascular Function Measurements and Muscle Strength 
Confirmation 
 Visit 5 consisted of the same cardiovascular measurements assessed in visit 3. The 1RM 
was confirmed as in visit 3. 
Anthropometrics 
 Height was measured using a stadiometer to the nearest 0.5 cm, and body weight was 
measured using a Seca Scale (Sunbeam Products, Boca Raton, FL) to the nearest 0.1 kg. BMI 
was calculated as kg/m2. Waist circumference was measured two times and was calculated to the 
nearest 0.1 cm using a tape measure at the level of the iliac crest after a normal expiration [130]. 
The average of two measurements at baseline and 6 weeks was used in the analysis. 
Cardiovascular Health/ History Questionnaire 
 The Cardiovascular Health/History Questionnaire was used to assess the subjects’ current 
health status for either inclusion or exclusion to the study. This questionnaire consisted of 

24 
 
multiple questions that indicated whether the subject had current or past underlying diseases, 
medical problems and/or conditions that affected the training regimen or measurements. 
Cardiovascular Parameters 
Pulse Wave Velocity 
 Following 10 min of rest in the supine position, brachial BPs and PWVs were measured 
using an automatic device (VP-2000; Omron Healthcare, Vernon Hills, IL). BP cuffs were 
wrapped around both arms (brachial artery) and ankles (posterior tibial artery), and 2 tonometers 
were placed over the right carotid and femoral arteries in order to obtain BP and PWV 
measurements from 3 arterial segments: baPWV, cfPWV, and faPWV. While baPWV is an 
accurate measurement of systemic arterial stiffness [51], cfPWV and faPWV are considered 
reliable measurements of aortic and leg arterial stiffness, respectively. PWV was calculated as 
the distance between 2 sites divided by the transit time. The distance from the carotid to the 
femoral artery was measured with a non-elastic tape measure as a straight line, while the distance 
between sampling points of baPWV and faPWV was automatically calculated according to the 
subject’s height [51]. The carotid and femoral arterial waveforms were recorded simultaneously 
by the tonometers, and the transient time was calculated automatically by relating the foot of 
each waveform to the R-wave of the ECG. HR was also obtained from the ECG. Two 
measurements were collected at each time point and averaged. 
Pulse Wave Analysis 
 Brachial systolic BP (SBP) and diastolic BP (DBP) were measured using an automatic 
device (VP-2000; Omron Healthcare, Vernon Hills, IL) and used to calibrate the radial 
waveforms obtained from a 10 sec epoch using a non-invasive pencil-like high-fidelit y 
transducer (SPT-301B; Millar Instruments, Houston, Texas, USA). The arterial pulse 

25 
 
waveforms (used to measure wave reflection and aortic BP) were obtained from the radial artery 
of the left arm using applanation tonometry. Aortic pressure waveforms were synthesized from 
the radial pressure waveform using a validated generalized transfer function (SphygmoCor; 
AtCor Medical, Sydney Australia). The aortic wave was composed of a forward wave (resulting 
from the ejection of the stroke volume) and a reflected wave (returns to the aorta from peripher al 
sites when it hits points of reflection). Additionally, AIx was defined as the augmentation 
pressure (AP) difference between P2 and P1 of the pressure wave, expressed as a perc entage of 
the aortic pulse pressure (difference between SBP and DBP). AIx was normalized for a HR of 
75 beats/min (AIx@75) due to the negative impact of HR on AIx [87,131]. Tr denotes the travel 
time of the forward wave to the peripheral reflecting sites and back to the aorta [132]. AIx and 
Tr were previously used as markers of wave reflection and aortic stiffness, respectively [133]. 
Body Composition 
 Total mass, total fat mass (FM), body fat (%), total lean mass (LM), arm LM, and leg LM 
were evaluated by a whole-body DEXA scan (Lunar TM DPX-IQ, Madison, WI). DEXA scans 
were conducted in the Exercise Physiology Laboratory in Florida State University. 
Measurements were conducted in the morning after an overnight fast (8-12 hrs). The 
participants were instructed to wear the same clothes before and after the 6 weeks (e.g. loose, 
comfortable clothing). 
Strength Testing 
 The 1RM was obtained by finding the maximum load the participant could move through 
a full range of motion for the leg press and chest press exercises following the ACSM guidelines 
for the 1RM strength test. The participant performed a light warm-up set of 10-12 repetitions on 
a MedXTM (Ocala, FL, USA) machine. Subsequent to the warm-up (10-15 repetitions) and a 2 

26 
 
min resting period, participants performed a maximal leg press through a full range of motion 
with controlled movement. The initial weight that is within the subject’s perceived capacity 
(50%-70% of capacity) was selected. The weight was increased by 2.5-20 kg until only one 
complete movement through the full range of motion could be achieved. The 1RM was attained 
within 3 to 5 attempts. If the participant exceeded 5 attempts, they were asked to return to the 
Exercise Physiology Laboratory to perform the strength test again within 48 hrs. The highest 
measurement for the leg press exercise was considered the 1RM [134]. Following the leg press 
1RM, the participant repeated the aforementioned protocol performing the chest press through 
the full range of motion. At least 72 hrs later, following the same warm-up, the participants 
confirmed the maximum weights achieved at the prior visit until a 1RM weight was achieved. 
The 1RM testing was supervised and recorded by the same trained researcher before and after 
the 6 weeks. 
Unloaded Whole-Body Vibration Training 
 Participants performed 3 supervised training sessions weekly for 6 weeks. The 
participants performed dynamic exercises for the legs on a vibration platform (Power Plate, 
Badhoevendorp, Netherlands). The exercises consisted of the following dynamic exercises: 
squats performed at a 90 degree knee angle, semi-squats performed at 120 degree knee ang le 
(180 degree considered a full knee extension), wide squat performed at a 90 degree knee angle, 
and calf-raises (maximal heel elevation). Dynamic exercises were performed with controlled 
movements at a rate of 3 seconds down and 3 seconds up (were controlled by the use of a 
metronome). The training volume progressively increased over the 6-week training period as 
follows: the intensity of the vibration (frequency: 30 to 35 Hz; amplitude: 1-2 mm) duration of 
the exercise set (30-60 sec), number of sets per each exercise (2-8) and total duration of the 

27 
 
training session (11-56 min) were increased. Also, rest periods (60 sec to 45 sec) were 
progressively decreased between sets. All training sessions were performed under careful 
supervision of certified personal trainers and researchers. All the participants performed the 
exercises barefoot to avoid any variations and/or alterations in the propagation of the vibration 
due to fabric (e.g. sock thickness). 
Externally Loaded, Resistive Whole Body-Vibration Training 
 Participants performed the same training sessions as the WBVT group for 6 weeks. 
However, an external load (contained in a vest) was added to perform 15-8 RM since a similar 
intensity using RT improved aortic and brachial BP in young obese men [100]. The exter nal 
load was assessed through a WBV strength test. The participant performed a 60 sec warm up of 
dynamic squats (frequency 30 Hz, amplitude 2 mm) with no additional load applied in the vest. 
The participant then rested for 2- 3 min. The 15% of the subject’s LM (from DEXA) was added 
to the vest as the initial weight to find out the necessary weight to perform a specific number of 
RM. The amount of weight applied to the vest was gradually increased based on the amount of 
repetitions the participant successfully completed with the external load. The external load was 
reassessed weekly to account for the proper amount of repetitions. 
Overweight/Obese Control Group 
 The O-CON group (no exercise overweight/obese control) did not perform any type of 
exercise during the 6 weeks. 
Lean Control Group 
 The L-CON group (no exercise lean control) did not perform any type of exercise during 
the 6 weeks.

Statistical Analysis 
Based on previous data [37], 14 subjects per group must be included in order to provide 
80% power (1-sided α= 0.05) to detect an 8% reduction in baPWV and a large effect size. 
Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS, version 21.0 (SPSS, Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). 
Normal distribution of the data was examined with the Shapiro-Wilk test. Unpaired-t-test was 
used to compare lean and overweight/obese women at baseline. One-way analysis of variance 
(ANOVA) was used to detect possible differences in parameters between overweight/obese 
women at baseline. Between and within treatment comparisons were performed with a two-way 
ANOVA with repeated measurements (treatments (WBVT+EX vs. WBVT vs. O-CON) x time (0 
weeks vs. 6 weeks)). When significant time and/or treatment-by-time interactions were found, 
paired t-tests and Tukey’s test were used for post-hoc comparisons. Statistical significance was 
set at P < 0.05. Data are presented as mean ± SE. 
 

29 
 
CHAPTER FOUR 
RESULTS 
 
Twenty-five subjects began either the WBVT or the WBVT+EX; however, 2 subjects 
dropped-out due to time commitment, while 1 subject dropped-out due to the use of tobacco 
products. These subjects were excluded from the study and statistical analysis. Thirteen young 
lean women were measured at baseline while 22 young overweight/obese women (BMI: 30.9 ± 
0.7 kg/m2) were stratified into completing 6 weeks of either a non-exercise control period (O-
CON), WBVT or WBVT+EX. Compliance to the training was 98 % for both WBVT and 
WBVT+EX. Both WBVT protocols consisted of a total of 18 sessions (3 times a week for 6 
weeks) performed on alternate days. Subjects were asked to maintain their regular diet and 
lifestyle (e.g. exercise habits). None of the women in the WBVT or WBVT+EX groups reported 
any adverse side-effects or unfavorable symptoms/signs resulting from the vibration stimulus. 
Lean vs. Overweight/ Obese Subjects at Baseline 
Baseline characteristics between lean and overweight/obese subjects are presented in 
Table 2. Age, height, baPWV, cfPWV, faPWV, bSBP, HR, Tr, chest 1RM, and leg 1RM were 
not significantly different between lean and overweight/obese subjects at baseline. Due to the 
experimental design, weight, BMI, WC, total FM, body fat (%), total LM, arm LM, leg LM ( P < 
0.001); bDBP, AIx, AIx@75, AP ( P < 0.05); aSBP, aDBP, aMAP, P1, and P2 ( P < 0.01) were 
higher in the overweight/obese subjects compared to the lean subjects at baseline.

Subject Characteristics, Body Composition, and Muscle Strength Following 6 Weeks in 
Overweight/Obese Subjects 
Subject characteristics, body composition, and muscle strength in the overweight/obese 
individuals at baseline and following the 6-week period are presented in Table 3. Age, height, 
weight, BMI, WC, total FM, body fat (%), total LM, arm LM, and leg LM did not differ within 
each group or amongst groups. However, following the 6 weeks, only the WBVT+EX group had 
a significant increase ( P < 0.01) in chest 1RM. Additionally, the WBVT and the WBVT+EX 
groups had significant increases in leg strength ( P < 0.01) when compared to the O-CON group 
(group-by-time P < 0.01) (Figure 9). 
Arterial Parameters Following 6-week Period in Overweight/Obese Subjects 
 Table 4 summarizes cardiovascular parameters before and after 6 weeks. There were no 
significant time effects or group-by-time interactions for bSBP, bDBP, AIx, AP, and Tr in any of 
the overweight/ obese groups. Compared to baseline measurements, P1, cfPWV ( P < 0.05), 
aortic SBP (aSBP), and P2 ( P < 0.01) significantly decreased in the WBVT group, while 
baPWV, aSBP, aDBP, AIx@75, P1, P2 ( P < 0.05), faPWV, and aMAP ( P < 0.01) also 
significantly decreased in the WBVT+EX group following the 6 weeks. In addition, the cfPWV 
(Figure 7), P1, and P2 in the WBVT were significantly different (P < 0.05) from the O-CON. 
Also, following the 6 weeks of training, the WBVT+EX group had significantly different faPWV 
(Figure 7), HR, aSBP (Figure 8), aMAP, AIx@75 (Figure 8), P1, and P2 ( P < 0.05) when 
compared to the O-CON group. 
Dietary Composition Following 6-week Period in Overweight/Obese Subjects 
Table 5 summarizes the dietary intake and composition of the overweight/obese subjects. 
Components were maintained amongst the training groups at baseline and after the 6-week 
period as verified via 3-day food logs.

CHAPTER FOUR 
DISCUSSION 
 
The present study evaluated the effects of 6 weeks of loaded and unloaded WBVT on 
arterial function, muscle strength, and body composition in sedentary, overweight/obese young 
women. To our knowledge, this is the first study to detect beneficial effects of WBVT+EX on 
arterial parameters, as seen by improvements in aortic BP, PWV, and wave reflection while still 
maintaining increases in muscle strength in young overweight/obese women. 
The primary findings of the current study were that aSBP, faPWV, and AIx@75, 
indicators of aortic BP, leg arterial stiffness and wave reflection, respectively, significantly 
decreased after 6 weeks of WBVT+EX when compared to O-CON. However, these 
improvements were not different between WBVT groups. Because increased CVD risk is 
accredited to the pathophysiological changes in the arterial system, especially increased arterial 
stiffness [135-136], the current study adds evidence of WBVT+EX being used as an effective 
exercise modality to attenuate the cardiovascular risk in young overweight/obese women. 
Likewise, arterial stiffness is a precursor of hypertension, rather than a consequence of high B P 
[137]. Hence, solely lowering BP is not sufficient to decrease the risk for cardiovascular events 
and mortality. Therefore, effective interventions targeting improvements in arterial function 
(e.g. decreases in arterial stiffness and wave reflection) are critical. 
Adaptations in Arterial Stiffness 
The most proficient exercise modality for improving arterial stiffness is still debatable. 
baPWV, an accurate measurement of systemic arterial stiffness [51], has been previously shown 
to decrease (0.9 m/s) in young overweight/obese women following 6 weeks of WBVT [37]. Yet, 

38 
 
the exact component (s) of the baPWV segment (cfPWV and/or faPWV) accountable for the 
reduction in baPWV was/were still uncertain. However, a recent study by our group following 
12 weeks of WBVT in postmenopausal women, established that the improvements observed in 
baPWV were attributed to a reduction in faPWV [65]. Similarly, in the present study, 
improvements in baPWV following WBVT+EX could be due to the reduction in faPWV and the 
tendency to decrease in cfPWV. These findings supplement the evidence suggesting that some 
portions of baPWV are determined by peripheral arterial stiffness, the largest component of 
baPWV. Likewise, baPWV decreased significantly (0.55 ± 0.20 m/sec) following 6 weeks of 
WBVT+EX, similar to decreases observed after 3 months of WBVT in middle aged-elderly 
subjects [138]. Interestingly, since baPWV has been positively correlated with cfPWV [52], the 
reductions in baPWV observed could provide similar information to those derived from cfPWV, 
which are favorable in clinical populations. Because an increase in baPWV by 1 m/s 
corresponds for a rise of 12%, 13%, and 6% in total cardiovascular events, cardiovascular 
mortality, and all-cause mortality [10], a reduction of 0.6 m/sec represents a clinically significant 
improvement that could have been underpowered due to the small sample size. 
Previous studies have indicated that obesity may increase cfPWV [12-13] and faPWV 
[139], while a recent study states no relationship between cfPWV and obesity [140]. However, 
no differences at baseline were observed between the lean and overweight/obese women in any 
of the PWV segments, indicating that whole-body and abdominal adiposity do not have a 
negative impact on arterial health at young age. In the current study, cfPWV decreased by 0.28 
m/sec ( P= 0.02 ) following 6 weeks of unloaded WBVT. This decrease is similar to those 
observed in older individuals (0.4 m/sec) on anti-hypertensive medication following 16 weeks of 
moderate/high intensity interval AT [154]. Previous studies in young and postmenopausal obese 

39 
 
women have not observed this effect after 6 to 12 weeks of unloaded WBVT. Although there 
were no between-group difference at baseline, cfPWV was 0.20-0.30 m/sec higher than the other 
two groups while the values at 6 weeks were similar. Interestingly, significant overestimation of 
cfPWV with increased central obesity in both men and women has been previously reported 
[141]. Therefore, the traveled distance measured over the body surface can be substantially 
overestimated with wider WC (WBVT women had greater WC although not significantly 
different between groups). 
Importantly, the progression of the external load was adapted from a prior study by 
Croymans et al. [100] which did not see changes in cfPWV after 12 weeks of high-intensity RT 
in young overweight/obese sedentary young men. However, Beck et al. [99] observed, for the 
first time, decreases in faPWV following 8 weeks of moderate/high intensity RT in young pre-
hypertensive men and women. Both studies were based on young pre-hypertensive individuals 
who are at a higher risk of CVD and, at the same time, are more prone to reductions in 
cardiovascular parameters because of the elevated value. It is imperative to mention, that, 
although our overweight/obese women were normotensive based on brachial SBP, they exhibited 
higher wave reflection (AIx and AP) and aortic BP values at baseline compared to the age-
matched lean group putting them in a greater risk for CVD due to an increased wave reflection 
and, therefore, left ventricular afterload despite normal PWV. Therefore, by adding an external 
load to WBV, the WBV exercise intensity was increased from low to moderate without causing 
the increases in PWV previously reported following moderate to high intensity RT [33-35, 94-
96]. 
Although previous studies have observed decreases in faPWV after WBVT in obese 
postmenopausal women [65], this is the first study to show decreases in young overweight/obese 

40 
 
women after 6 weeks of WBVT+EX, an improvement not observed following WBVT. W e 
observed that WBVT+EX significantly decreased faPWV (-0.41 ± 0.10 m/sec) when compared 
to the O-CON. Notably, a previous study following 60 days of bed rest observed that combining 
resistance exercise with vibration (but not without) partly prevented the undesirable increase in 
wall:lumen ratio of the superficial femoral artery [46]. Therefore, the mechanical stimulus to the 
leg arteries during the vibration exposure could explain improvements in lower extremity 
hemodynamics [41]. This increase in blood flow to the lower extremity could possibly cause a 
constant exposure of shear stress, which up-regulates NO production [110], eliciting vasodilation 
and acute decrease in arterial stiffness. Additionally, WBVT alone and WBVT plus RT [142] 
have also been previously linked to significant increases in circulating NO in young active 
women. Evidently, repeated bouts of acute exercise are key contributors to chronic adaptations 
[109], which are reflected in the current study. This proposed underlying mechanism for the 
improvements in faPWV although likely, should be confirmed in future studies through 
measurements of plasma levels of circulating endothelial factors. Thus, the use of WBVT+EX 
for reducing cardiovascular risk (particularly faPWV) in previously physically inactive 
overweight/obese women has a more evident vascular effect due to a higher intensity stimulus 
than unloaded WBVT. 
Adaptations in Blood Pressures and Central Pressure Waveform Properties 
 Brachial BP was not different between the overweight/obese and lean groups at baseline. 
Likewise, training for 6 weeks did not significantly affect brachial BP as expected because our 
participants were normotensives. Unlike current results, a study [37] observed significant 
decreases in bSBP and bDBP following 6 weeks of WBVT in young overweight/obese women. 
Although women in the previous study had similar characteristics (e.g. age, body weight, BMI) 

41 
 
as participants in the present study, variations in baseline brachial BP are evident between 
studies (~117mmHg vs. ~109mmHg). Also, the previous study was a crossover design in which 
10 women were randomized in either WBVT or a non-exercising control group for 6 weeks, 
followed by a 4 week wash-out period. Although unlikely, variations may exist between wash-
out periods as well as the small sample size. Yet, aortic BP relate more to adverse 
cardiovascular events than brachial BP since central BP more accurately reflect the loading 
conditions of the left ventricular myocardium [155]. Therefore, brachial BP is not as sensitive of 
a marker to expose changes in arterial function between young lean and age-matched 
overweight/obese sedentary women. 
In the present study, both WBVT groups reduced aSBP; however, only WBVT+EX was 
different from the O-CON group following the 6 weeks. These reductions observed in aSBP are 
consistent with findings of a previous study by our group that showed decreases of ~5 mmHg in 
young overweight/obese women after 6 weeks of WBVT [37]. Reductions in aSBP were also 
observed following 6 weeks of WBVT in postmenopausal women with 
prehypertension/hypertension (~11 mmHg) [64], which had significantly greater baseline values 
as well as higher CVD risk. Interestingly, in agreement with the present study, 12 weeks of R T 
in young overweight/obese men [100] resulted in significant reduction in aSBP (5 mmHg) 
despite showing no alterations in AIx or cfPWV. Because an increase in the magnitude of the 
wave reflection augments aSBP and leads to increases in AP and AIx (the difference between the 
second (P2) and the first (P1) systolic peak in relation to aortic pulse pressure), the decreases in 
aSBP are vital for improvements in left ventricular afterload [7]. In the current study, the 
overweight/obese women had significantly higher AIx at baseline when compared to their age-
matched lean group, which confirms the prior link between elevated levels of AIx and obese 

42 
 
individuals [15]. Because concurrent decreases in P1 and P2 significantly occurred in both 
WBVT groups when compared to O-CON, AP was not significantly altered. Indeed, because 
HR increased after 6 weeks of WBVT+EX and AIx and HR are inversely related [87, 131], when 
AIx was adjusted to 75 bpm (AIx@75), improvements in the WBVT+EX compared to O-CON 
group were evident. This rationale is in accordance with a previous study following low-
intensity RT in obese postmenopausal women [143] which also observed the lack of significant 
decrease in AIx accompanied by concurrent decreases in P1 and P2. Likewise, because no 
change was observed in Tr and cfPWV, the reduction in AIx@75 was not influenced by aortic 
stiffness [37,88]. Consequently, the decreases observed in aSBP and AIx@75 following 
WBVT+EX could be justified via improvements in wave reflection as result of improved 
peripheral arterial stiffness [99]. Our results are in agreement with a study by Beck et al. [ 99] 
who showed decreases in these variables following 8 weeks of moderate/high intensity RT. 
Therefore, favorable decreases following only 6 weeks of WBVT+EX in aortic BP, wave 
reflection, and consequently, left ventricular afterload, hold strong clinical implications for 
young overweight/obese women. 
Adaptations in Muscle Strength and Function 
As anticipated, both WBVT groups significantly improved following the 6 weeks of 
training. Markedly, these improvements were different from the O-CON group but not different 
between training groups. These results are in accordance with previous studies [37, 61, 64, 117], 
which observed significant improvements in leg muscle strength in untrained young and old 
women, following 6 to 12 weeks of WBVT. Notably, the training frequencies for both WBVT 
interventions were 3 days per week. In agreement with our study, research suggests that 
untrained individuals exhibit the highest muscle strength gains following 3 days per week 

43 
 
training frequencies [144]. Moreover, the current training protocol was adapted from previous 
training studies that incorporated static and dynamic leg exercises [37, 61, 65]. Although WBV 
can be performed with static or dynamic movements, dynamic exercises seem to exhibit greater 
advantages than static exercises [145]. Previous studies have observed greater increases in 
muscle force production following dynamic exercises when compared to static [146-149]. 
Likewise, a recent study by Bush et al. [145] sought to determine the effects of dynami c versus 
static squats performed during WBV on muscle force and strength. Performing dynamic 
exercises during WBV resulted in greater benefits than the same exercise without WBV and 
static exercises (with/without vibration). These favorable effects of dynamic exercises were 
attributed to possible increments in functional movement patterns and higher degree of muscle 
fiber recruitment. Performing static exercises seem to elicit higher levels of fatigability (H + ion 
buildup) due, possibly, to mechanical compression resulting from the maintained position. 
Besides, no changes were observed in leg LM following either WBVT groups. Thus, taken 
together, the increases in leg muscle strength observed in our study after only 6 weeks of training 
are the result of increases in neurological activity and improvements in functional modifications 
(e.g. increase in firing rate, fiber recruitment) [150-151]. However, it seems that a potential 
difference between WBVT groups in strength acquisition could have been underpowered due to 
the small sample size. Possibly, a larger sample size and longer training durations are required to 
to observe a notable difference between WBVT and WBVT+EX in young overweight/obese 
women. Also, more precise body composition measurements (e.g. magnetic resonance imaging) 
as well as longer training durations are necessary (e.g. 10 weeks of WBV) to improve LM [61]. 
Moreover, previous studies have evaluated the impact of external load positioning (e.g. chest 
versus hips) on VO2max [156] and muscle power [157]. Although unexpected, because increases 

44 
 
in chest 1RM were only observed in the WBVT+EX (the extra weight was applied to a weight 
vest in the thorax ), we attribute the improvements to possible neural adaptations of the anterior 
deltoid and pectoralis mayor (muscles involved in the chest press exercise). Interestingly, the 
increases in muscle strength seen in this study have strong clinical implications since muscle 
strength tends to decline at a faster rate than muscle mass [152]. Therefore, WBVT and 
WBVT+EX are feasibly strategies to possibly attenuate the loss of muscle strength and mass 
observed with age and chronic diseases. 
Limitations 
 Various limitations exist in the present study. The small sample size in the 
overweight/obese groups concealed some tendencies in the data analysis. These trends would 
otherwise aid in explaining some physiological modifications that persisted following the 
interventions. Moreover, a clear mechanism to explain the results cannot be proposed due to 
lack of measurements of endothelial function (e.g. plasma levels of circulating endothelial 
factors and flow-mediated dilation) and sympathetic activity (e.g. heart rate variability, 
baroreflex sensitivity, muscle nerve sympathetic activity). These measurements are valuable in 
the interpretation of any potential benefits following this exercise intervention. Also, the 
measurements of arterial function were performed taking into account the participants’ self -
reported first day of the menstrual cycle. The assessment of plasma estrogen levels would have 
confirmed that the measurements were performed during the follicular or late luteal phase of the 
women’s menstrual cycle. Furthermore, the WBVT protocol used in this particular study had 
unique characteristics (e.g. dynamic movements, sets, rest times, exercises, vibration frequency 
and amplitude, and weight applied to the vest in the WBVT+EX). Therefore, this limits the 

45 
 
comparability to other studies utilizing other WBVT protocols or exercise modality (e.g., 
conventional RT). 
Future Studies 
 This study evaluated the effects of 6 weeks of WBVT+EX on arterial function, muscle 
strength, and body composition in young overweight/obese women. This is the first study to 
show that 6 weeks of WBVT+EX elicits significant improvements in aSBP, faPWV, and 
AIx@75 while still provoking increases in muscle strength in this population. Future research 
should focus on longer training periods (e.g. 3 and 6 months) in order to have stronger 
observations of alterations in arterial function, muscle strength, and body composition (mainly 
LM). Also, although women in the current study are considered an at-risk sedentary population 
(fell into a BMI category between 27 and 40 kg/m 2), they are still apparently healthy, young 
premenopausal women free of any chronic diseases. Future studies should target older 
populations with greater risks of cardiovascular and/or other chronic diseases that require an 
increase in muscle strength/mass without the deleterious effects on arterial function caused by 
high intensity RT. Additional studies should consider the use of WBVT+EX as an adjunct 
exercise modality in order to propagate its use in clinical populations prone to physical 
disabilities due to sarcopenia and dynapenia. Moreover, the most effective exercise modality for 
the treatment of arterial stiffness has yet to be established. Yet, the current study adds to the 
understanding of combining two exercise modalities and their benefits in young 
overweight/obese women.
sections.conclusions:
The current study indicates that WBVT and WBVT+EX are effective approach es in 
reducing arterial dysfunction while improving leg muscle strength in young, sedentary 

46 
 
overweight/obese women. However, WBVT+EX is a more evident stimulus as seen in 
reductions in aSBP, leg arterial stiffness, and wave reflection otherwise not observed after 
WBVT. We aimed to examine the effects of WBVT+EX on: 1) arterial stiffness and function; 2) 
muscle strength; 3) body composition. Although unloaded WBVT seems to be an effective 
exercise modality to improve arterial function in obese postmenopausal women, it does not seem 
to be as efficient in young obese women. This study suggests that a more evident benefit on 
arterial function is observed after increasing the exercise intensity of WBVT through an external 
load progressed from 15 to 8 RM. Future studies should focus on older populations with greater 
risk of cardiovascular and/or other chronic diseases that are associated with reduced muscle 
strength/mass. WBVT+EX should be incorporated and recommended for young 
overweight/obese women in order to improve arterial function and prevent the loss in muscle 
mass related to weight loss. Additional studies should consider the use of WBVT+EX as an 
adjunct exercise modality in order to incorporate its use in clinical populations prone to physical 
disabilities due to sarcopenia and dynapenia.

1. Lobstein, T. and R. Jackson-Leach, Child overweight and obesity in the USA: prevalence 
rates according to IOTF definitions. Int J Pediatr Obes, 2007. 2(1): p. 62-4. 
 
2. Melanson, K.J., et al., Obesity and cardiovascular disease risk: research update. Cardiol
